<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>

<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_connection_set_initial_state_:
```c
void
MHD_connection_set_initial_state_ (struct MHD_Connection *c)
{
  size_t read_buf_size;

#ifdef HTTPS_SUPPORT
  mhd_assert ( (0 == (c->daemon->options & MHD_USE_TLS)) || \
               (MHD_TLS_CONN_INIT == c->tls_state) );
  mhd_assert ( (0 != (c->daemon->options & MHD_USE_TLS)) || \
               (MHD_TLS_CONN_NO_TLS == c->tls_state) );
#endif /* HTTPS_SUPPORT */
  mhd_assert (MHD_CONNECTION_INIT == c->state);

  c->keepalive = MHD_CONN_KEEPALIVE_UNKOWN;
  c->event_loop_info = MHD_EVENT_LOOP_INFO_READ;

  memset (&c->rq, 0, sizeof(c->rq));
  memset (&c->rp, 0, sizeof(c->rp));

  c->write_buffer = NULL;
  c->write_buffer_size = 0;
  c->write_buffer_send_offset = 0;
  c->write_buffer_append_offset = 0;

  c->continue_message_write_offset = 0;

  c->read_buffer_offset = 0;
  read_buf_size = c->daemon->pool_size / 2;
  c->read_buffer
    = MHD_pool_allocate (c->pool,
                         read_buf_size,
                         false);
  c->read_buffer_size = read_buf_size;
}
```

explanation: No controlling statements (if, switch, while, for, do-while) are present in the provided function body; Rule 14.3 applies to controlling expressions of such constructs. The code contains only assignments, function calls, memset, and preprocessor conditionals. The #ifdef/endif are preprocessor directives (not C controlling expressions) and therefore are not subject to Rule 14.3 in this source fragment. The mhd_assert(...) lines supply boolean expressions as macro arguments but are macro invocations rather than explicit controlling statements in this code. Without the macro definition, we cannot see any controlling expression introduced by the macro expansion; if desired, the mhd_assert macro definition should be reviewed separately to ensure it does not expand into an invariant controlling expression. Based on the visible source alone, there are no controlling expressions to investigate for invariance, so no suspicious fragments are reported.
